subject: Ang: RE: [junit] Junit and EJBs
msgSnippet: I agree with Mike here - and would even go one step further. Using junit and tdd with session ejbs encourages the ejb front pattern (is this the right name?)
messageBody:
I agree with Mike here - and would even go one step further. Using junit
and tdd with session ejbs encourages the 'ejb front' pattern (is this the
right name?) which is a good thing.

Cactus has both pros and cons.

Steven Hale

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Mike Clark [mailto:mike@...]
> Sent: 04 April 2003 01:59
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: Re: [junit] Junit and EJBs
>
> John Lindwall wrote:
>
> >We wanted to build a suite of unit tests for our session beans. We
> looked at Cactus and played with it a bit and were put off by some of
the
> effort involved in making it work. You have to address various client
vs
> server deployment issues, it seems confusiong wrt what code is
executed in
> the client vs the server ,etc.
> >
> >We decided not to devote that level of effort to Cactus just yet and
> instead are writing unit tests that act as clients to the session
beans
> and testing them in that manner using the normal test runner.
> >
> >It's not clear to me what the disadvantages are to this approach.
> Comments?
> >
>
> I've found no significant disadvantages to using this approach to
> testing remotely-accessible methods of EJB components. Then again,
when
> I do use EJBs it's only to "front" a non-EJB component that can be
> tested outside of an EJB container. That is, the EJB is strictly
> conduit. So I guess I use the approach you mention for integration
> testing, if that distinction matters.
>
> IMO, Cactus is great, if you absolutely must test from within the
> container. I strive to make those cases the exception, rather than
the
> rule.
>
> Mike
